target_text: "It is important to also assure internal quality. Internal quality has to do with the way that the system has been built and designed."

Role.Subject: Statistics
Role.positionality: I am a software developer pursuing a bachelor’s degree in statistics, bringing computational pragmatism to economic questions. My research goal is to build reproducible, data-driven analyses that translate statistical evidence into policy-relevant economic insights. I acknowledge cultural and personal biases—favoring algorithmic efficiency, market-oriented explanations, and English-language sources—that shape what I read, model, and report. I reflect on how the question’s framing and the user’s response interact with my background to prioritize hypotheses, steer goals toward tractable problems, amplify biases, and narrow interpretations; thus I employ transparency, alternative specifications, and robustness checks to counterbalance these influences.

Codebook.role: Reflective Researcher (PhD-level; QS: Information Systems; NSF: Human-Centered Computing; reflexivity: process-metrics/governance bias)

codebook.justification: [It is important to also assure internal quality.] From an IS/HCI, PhD-level lens on trustworthy systems, this is a normative priority rather than an objective measure.

[Internal quality has to do with the way that the system has been built and designed.] This centers architectural and UX process heuristics; my process-metrics bias elevates design judgments over outcome metrics.
[assure internal quality] signals a QA/governance orientation; as a reflexive researcher, I read this as contingent on evaluators’ criteria and risk appetite.
